msdTGTtkcQkqGCjZjNCGJw.text: The manager of this establishment is a true professional, and an exceptionally charming hostess. She managed to fit our group of 4 in on a busy Sunday for a quick one-course roast meal, which was delightful.I had the salmon, which was cooked crispy and came with buttery Hollandaise sauce. I'd love to come back in the evening someday and try the dinner menu.

u2Kb4Ikxx-ItEbDrX14w7w.text: Looking for fabulous, inexpensive food in Kensington? Head here for some of the tastiest British food I've had in a while! Kedgeree, Cauliflower Cheese, mashed potato, pies, homemade soups, it's all their on the menu. £5 for starters and £7 for mains. They even have a specials board and a cute waiter... perfect! The place itself is super cute, cosy nooks and crannies to snuggle in, plates, jugs, saddles nailed to the wall. And not in a comical, tacky way. This actually looks like the inside of a pub dining room close to the village my parents live in. The staff if a little snarky about the fact we wanted to try almost all the sides and only one main between us were very helpful and our food came out super quick.This really is one of the best dining options in the area, really it should be 5 stars but I think I'm just going to have to try it again to make sure!

6l_40KC7BaAMKPrr7HxBAw.text: The man took me here for Valentine's day, and I must say he pulled it off very well.  I love the cluttered, rustic nature of it - it's a fresh change from all the swanky places in the area.  The decor is definitely the most memorable aspect to this place; I love the huge square table upstairs where about 15 people could sit around, as well as the private romantic booths just next to it and all the dried flowers hanging from the wooden ceilings.  You feel like you're in a buzzy place, but at the same time you can be very romantic and removed, candle light and all if you choose.I'm generally not a huge fan of British food, but the French onion soup and asparagus and mushroom pie I had were both as good as they can be, and the man's crab salad was delish.  He loved the lamb too, unfortunately half of it ended up on his shirt.Great wine list too.  I'd recommend this place more for the entertainment and unique factor rather than the food, but I don't think anyone would walk away from here feeling unfulfilled, she's a special one that Maggie Jones's.

ep7cHS2YG8QlgYZVasu0gA.text: Maggie Jones is a great and amazing restaurant in London.  Every time the family goes to London (was a lot more often when i worked for an airline) we make it a point to get at least one meal in at Maggie Jones.  Food is always great (although not cheap) service outstanding with very personable staff.  Love the house wine that they measure with a stick once you finish it.Atmosphere is unique - lots of stuff, very cozy and casual - I like the large table on the top floor for larger groups or the small booths in the basement floor for a party of four - you can't go wrong.   The other review do far better justice to this place so read them as well.

wMLGA9dmiS3KA_qeb8Oevg.text: I'd forgotten how dimly-lit Maggie Jones's is, but my eyes soon adjusted.  Some places, this would ring alarm bells, what does the chef have to hide?  But at Maggie Jones's it just adds to the rustic, intimate atmosphere.Service was welcoming, helpful and friendly without being obtrusive and the food was good, classic British fare.  My steak was very enjoyable, if not quite as memorable as on a previous visit, and my bread and butter pudding was as good as such gets.  I'd suggested MJ's for a meet-up with my cousins and their husbands, and everyone seemed pleased with it.My only criticisms would be that the food was a tad slow to arrive after ordering, and whilst good, it's fairly pricy (especially as veg is not included with the mains and has to be ordered as sides).  But this /is/ Kensington, and I shudder to think what the overheads must be like.

FK-brX7XSJDOXjJxJX0SjQ.text: Wow! Great English food and great ambience! I tried the lamp rump... sooo tasty. Definitely with checking out!

BcxwA1H2Nm9-RhWoJjmRLw.text: The concierge at the Kensington area hotel we were staying at for the weekend put Maggie Jones on a list of  recommended spots- we were so glad that we choose this for our Saturday evening dining spot!We arrived after 8pm, and without a reservation.  They were able to get us in at a unshared table- the last one available for that evening.  I would  recommend reservations for anyone wanting to dine here.The decor is a bit cluttered and chaotic, but the candle-lit ambiance manages to be warm, homey and utterly romantic.  The service was attentive without being overbearing; the food simple, well prepared and delicious.  Also- they had quite a few vegetarian selections worked into the menu, not just to appease the occasional non-meat eater, but to entice both carnivores and herbivores alike.

4P89p-1HSw2WKcphqInbKw.text: I went here with colleagues on a business trip. The hostess couldn't have been any more accommodating. We showed up 15 minutes late for our reservation (we got lost walking there). The hostess sat us at a table in the front while she waited for a better situated booth to open up.The service was superb. Attentive but not overbearing. The food and decor make you feel like you've been invited  over to someone's house for dinner. I had the mushroom soup and chicken/artichoke pie. My colleague had venison. The apple crisp desert was baked to order. If you're looking for a small, intimate restaurant with traditional British food with a new world twist and top notch service this is the place to go. I will definitely return.

Z9uZIiDEo26Tqk70jusRcQ.text: I haven't been here in a while but I was a bit disappointed when I finally went on a dinner here last night. It seemed nothing like before and maybe it was me but the place seemed too ordinary and dull to catch my eye. Food was good, service  not so much.

Yl5KX71d76ADLNYsc5ZLNQ.text: Awesome place with real British food.  The staff are friendly (even to us Yanks!) and the food is always very good.  I have been here a number of times and the quality is a always good no matter what I order.  This is a good place to take out of town guests to help change their mind about English food.

dSz3-b1HnQALBiu5fUxDZA.text: The food was great, the people were great, and the atmosphere was most enjoyable.  We did not get out of there cheaply, but I don't regret it at all.I think perhaps the most memorable bit aside from the atmosphere is the house wine.  Order a 1.5l bottle of house and they will charge you for how much you drink, rather than the full bottle.  A great way to just have as much or as little as you want... though we perhaps drank more of it than intended...

4d3TFWoeNdkTLP8CCQeCqQ.text: Entering Maggie Jones, one leaves behind the bustle of High Street Kensington for what at first glance looks like an antique store.  But continue on for this antique store just happens to specialize in splendid renditions of English comfort food.  The service is unfailingly friendly.  The pot pies will make you think of Sundays long ago.

FoXMATIdft_bfyiwnCDlqA.text: The atmosphere is incredible!  The staff was extremely friendly.  We called and were able to get a same day reservation.  We arrived 25 minutes early and they were able to seat us.  You must visit this restaurant if you're in London!

XUtZlSnIoDF0HmtSp_HyZA.text: The decor in this place is warm and inviting, original English furniture and crockery, dim lights & candles. It's probably the main and only reason to go though. The menu is full of traditional English home cooking of the sort that most will remember from childhood, but it is overpriced by about 30% and ours seemed to have been prepared without much care and attention. My potted prawns were 'nice' enough, but accompanied by what looked and tasted like Hovis bread and my main course was tough and uninspiring. I reckon most high street supermarket premium ready meals would make a tastier meal. When I went it was full of Americans, and I guess really that's what it is for - tourists looking for the olde world. If you want good food - avoid.

jqYcN2vMRgRYZCM2--D6-g.text: Super cozy spot. Think Il Buco in NYC. Perfect for a date.  Food is decent.  They also have a daily game selection.

GiIQt6QqQ9G4oIprwQYVXw.text: Traditional English food at reasonable prices, in a great setting and convenient location.  Attentive service, easily manageable wine list, with some unique touches.The setting/ambience is the best part -- antiques and old tools/utensils decorate the walls, along with dried flowers, giving it a nice country feel without appearing to be trying too hard.  Weathered wooden tables, flooring, walls, and shuttered booths.  Very nicely done.I was able to walk in and get a table for two on a Thursday evening, which was also appreciated.

VydLwz3JNtNzymYxMSqwzg.text: Took my client and team to dinner last night and had a wonderful experience.  Food was top-notch and the atmosphere was cozy, but lively.  The lamb got rave reviews from all that ordered it, as did the onion soup..  The chocolate pot and brunt creme were excellent desserts as well.

giB5xb5oYTTwdbgr2Uq7IA.text: There are many things I love about London, one of them being the in-your-face juxtaposition of Old and New.  Sleek skyscapers and 1000 year old cathedrals.  The prim royals and the uh...not so prim royals.  You get the picture.  Anyway, Maggie Jones embodies this paradox.The servers are New.  I've been here multiple times, and it seems that no one over the age of 35 is allowed to work here, at least not in the dining rooms.  The attitude is New.  The waitstaff is completely laid back, and will stop and chat with you.  We were once here on New Year's Eve, and judging by the raucous revelers in various parts of the restaurant, most of the clientele are New.The building is Old.  Stuff is hanging from every possible surface, worn floorboards, and creaky staircases.  The food is also Old.  No, not the actual food that you eat, but the cuisine.  It's the most hearty, delicious, comforting, traditional British food you can imagine - exquisite roasts, delicious veggies, things topped with cheese, accented with delectable cream sauces and so forth.So there you go - Maggie Jones.  Old and New in one hard-to-find, yet worth the effort, address.  Add it to your list of "must dos" while in London.

v9omMvAQi7leVorgtzKuQQ.text: Serendipity, thy name is Maggie Jones.Wandering through Kensington High Street with nary an M&S open for a lazy bite, my fellow weary traveling buddies and I were running out of options.  Not only was it a crappy, damp Sunday night - but it was closing time.  It seemed in the stars that we had happened upon this place.  The ambiance, the service, the food - was perfect.  We were seated under the stipulation that we would have a limited menu due to the restaurant closing soon, but they were nonetheless willing to accommodate (and let me tell you, it can't be an easy feat to convince a chef to cook an allergy-free meal when he's ready to go home).  The salad tasted like it was harvested that morning.  The broiled fish was simple yet satisfying.  The crème brûlée was the best I've had since France.  The waitstaff was incredibly attentive and friendly.On top of that, I could not stop taking pictures of the damn place because it was so beautiful inside - like a sexy country cottage.  Definitely not a place for a bunch of greasy travelers like us.. this is a place to take your sweetheart!

S2tI6U29C2hvJnFa4L1ORw.text: Discovered this place by chance when taking a stroll on High Kensington Road.  Looked very warm and inviting, and I wasn't disappointed!  The atmosphere is old world rustic with low lighting and lots of candlelight.  Reservations were required, but I got there early and the host was kind enough to offer a small table upstairs.  Had the venison with red cabbage and chips, a delicious and filling onion soup, and "burnt cream" (aka creme brulee) for dessert.  All was delicious (even the filtered coffee was great)!  However, the price point is a little high (100 pounds for a dinner for 2 people, without alcohol... about 163$ CDN).  A nice experience, but might not return due to price.

lWlZvqci9bofe0xLlpAtjA.text: This is starting to be a must whenever in London.  Great traditional british food indeed!It is a small place so make sure you make reservations.  The place is nice and cozy and makes you want to drink hot chocolate. Check out the specials board before you order because they always have some new exciting dishes.For starters, I recommend the duck liver pate from the menu.  On the Specials that night, they had the venison terrine and the stilton and bacon salad that were delicious! We also ordered the wild boar sausage from the mains as an appetizer and it was also great! For the mains, I ordered the fish pie and it was creamy, flavorful, with a nice crusty pastry.  My friends ordered the steak and kidney pie and the chicken and artichoke pie --- and among the three, the winner was the steak and kidney pie.  The others ordered the rack of lamb, the rump of lamb and the stuffed pork.  The rack of lamb was delicious!  I want to come back so I can order the steak and kidney pie all for myself!For dessert, I recommend the chocolate pot and the bread and butter pudding.  I tried these three years ago and when we decided to go to London again, this was the first thing that came to my mind.  I wanted to go to Maggie Jones to order these two desserts!

jXhhzv0NFf522ci4lKlBMQ.text: I have been wanting to come here for years.  Finally got to visit twice in one week.  The first visit was with two friends. The second was with a group of 16 friends. On both occassions I loved this place. It is excellent for a small group as well as a large party.On my first visit I had the calf's, which was delicious.  The portions do not come up small, so I settled for sorbet for desert.On the second occassion, I had to chose from a set menu (huge selection though), as we were in a group of more than 10.  I had the pate to start, which was also good. For main, I went for roast lamb. Again very good. The set menu comes with a huge selection of vegetables. The coliflower cheese was excellent. I had apple crumble and custard for desert, which was perhaps too heavy for me after the other two courses.The atmosphe is great as is the service.  Would highly recommend, and would not hesitate in returning. Loved it!!

yuirzRkWW8N6z6xk_HwmMg.text: Dined here for our birthdays in February (another overdue review) and had a fantastic experience! Super cozy and rustic; even though we were in the heart of Kensington, while inside you can't help but think you're in a cabin restaurant in the country, nice after roaming the streets of London all day in the dead of winter.Food was spectacular, the gentleman that waited on us was super knowledgeable of the menu and helped us make a decision (everything on the menu looked too good to pass up). Good scotch and whiskey selection (again, good on a cold and rainy day) and the other couples dining in the restaurant that evening were very friendly and helpful in giving us other great places to visit while in town.Definitely will be stopping there again on our next visit in the fall!

ogG-cH1FX0Q22snvl1a6ZA.text: Absolutely charming venue for a winter lunch. It's a good sign you can leave a restaurant having really enjoyed the lunch despite there having been a problem with the starters not arriving!An immediate acknowledgement of the problem backed by a no-quibble deduction on the bill was appreciated, but the delicious food in a warm and friendly environment more than made up for it.I look forward to returning!

M6I4knZExcDsA887zbEzZg.text: Hmm. I've been here twice now and I feel a bit confused on the best way to review this place.First, above all else, this place is pure atmosphere. I think it's one of the dishiest rustic environments, while remaining just classy enough to make it a perfect date spot, or an intimate night out with close friends.Of course, food matters just as much in these locations, and that's where the confusion sets in. I've had great food here, and now I've had boring food here. Partridge night: This was my first time having partridge, and although difficult to eat, it was quite enjoyable here. I opted for the red cabbage and bacon/peas as a side. The accompanying gravy and hollandaise were lovely, and obviously made with care. Everything was moderately spiced, but quite enjoyable overall. The onion tart was extremely pricey for the size (9 pounds!!!) but was simple perfection. Overall, it was simple food done really well and I left quite pleased with Maggie Jones's.Bream night: Dining again, I tried the sea bream while my friend had the fillet. It was at this point my alarm was raised. Both the sea bream (18.50 I think) and the fillet (26.50) were acceptable..but very lackluster for the price. The fillet was especially forgettable and small; this is outrageous for the pricetag. I believe it was the most expensive item on the menu and it was easily the most disappointing. My sea bream was solid, but left too untouched to be standout. It was a nice cut of fish..that's it! The next problem was that both of these dishes did not come with any sides...so at this point we've spent over 40 pounds for a small fish, a mediocre steak...and nothing else. Very hard to internalize. Fortunately I ordered the cauliflower cheese, which was nice but yet again lacking finesse in the long run. We then tried dessert. I had the bread pudding, which was a bit boring but definitely edible..I feel that was the point so I wasn't too concerned. My dining mate said the creme brulee was fantastic, though topped with a bit too much sugar for his liking.It's interesting to note that my first trip here was when they were busy, and the second trip while they just opened. Odd.I think that you should go here for more traditional food: pies and tarts, rumps and roasts.  The atmosphere suggests that it's a classic British restaurant, so go with that feeling. For all the timeless recipes, they have odd items like crab and avocado which simply do not fit in. I wish this place cut about 10 items off of it and focused on what they are good at.I must reiterate that MJ's is one of the most romantic places I have been. Service is nice and you will feel at home instantly.

dlD0RoD709catp873XDr8g.text: The sort of place that reminds you how good (and comforting) British food can be! As Maggie Jones's is particularly good at chasing away the gloomy cold outside, warm up with cauliflower cheese, peas and bacon and mashed potatoes inside this rustic restaurant.Now that I've had their lunch, I can't wait to try Sunday roast!

9UXggCnxckBP-q4EyYu0Ww.text: This place has a really nice atmosphere, a real rustic feel.  Service was a little slow for us Americans, but we had just gotten into London, so maybe we weren't acclimated to the Euro pace yet.  We showed up without reservations, and they were busy, but the host was really nice and accomodating, giving us a table when a previous reservation didn't show.  (Recommendations are very important for the nicer restaurants, we've discovered.)We ordered the chicken pie, a cheese tart, and the cheesy cauliflower.  I really liked my pie and my wife her tart.  The cauliflower was good, but not as amazing as some of the other reviews made it out to be.  Prices are on the higher side, but everything tasted really fresh.I think it would have normally been a more subdued dining environment, but there was a large dinner party next to us that appeared to be thoroughly enjoying itself.All in all, a quality establishment.  Worth going to, but a bit pricey.  I think we would try different places before we need to return for seconds.

6M8QMXk3S89zzj_kk7KgDg.text: Wasn't exactly our "cup of tea" -- high reviews made this feel like someplace we should go but we left pretty disappointed. We a sat in the basement which was too dimly lit, requiring us to use our iPhone to shine a light on the chalkboard menu. We asked for the Sunday roast which was OK, but the desert was (a pudding) was positively atrocious. This place is probably great for locals that are looking for a roast like Mom used to make, but for those of you that are in from out of town I would avoid it.

NoNAPp4rBhwHfUVV5T7Jgg.text: Amazing food and service, great rustic location to go to.  Kind of hidden away, but this is definitely Kensington's little gem.  I can not rate this place any higher; i have been twice and last time i had the veal, cooked to perfection as were the compliments too.

uLTU-3biPqKg477GsC7A1A.text: One of the best meals I've had in London! Highly highly recommend. Everything was wonderful- my sister and I ordered the Scottish rump roast with red wine and mushroom sauce, and chips, and the rump roast of lamb with red cabbage. All so so yummy. Service was great and very attentive. Don't miss this place!

55D4s4WZbXrvgj2436NPDQ.text: This place is a definite gem. A one of a kind, unique, dining experience that you can't find just anywhere. First, trying to make a reservation from the US was no problem. I emailed the contact and they were extremely accommodating and helpful in getting us a seat. Even when I changed the time at the last minute (via email no less), they were extremely friendly about it and when we arrived, they had noted the change and had us seated immediately.What makes this place special beyond the excellent food was the DECOR and AMBIANCE: about the most charming restaurant that I have ever eaten in. My wife and i had a nice romantic booth with candles and the privacy we needed to have a fantastic dinner with conversation we don't normally get to enjoy with our 2 year old at the table :)The food was great as well, not the best we had while in London, but definitely high quality and delicious. Would definitely go back and recommend this place to travelers looking for a friendly and warm dining experience.

oo2RMLVbs8aplFIVfBVw2A.text: Wake up Maggie I think I got something to say to you: I like you, I really like you. I know your last name isn't May, but I don't care, you're lovely and you warmed my heart.When I had some friends visiting from out of town that wanted to meet for dinner, I suggested we should go for traditional British fare. When in Britain, right? In my quest for an amazing British meal, Maggie Jones's popped up. To be honest, it wasn't my first choice (I was going for something a bit more fine dining), but my friends seemed into it, so here we came.I'm so glad we did. The decor is fantastic. There's an eclectic mix of things hanging from the walls. It's a bit retro, but yet cool and modern and they aren't trying too hard so they don't come off as being too hipster. Weirdly, for a British restaurant the music playing was only 50's and 60's American. There are special boards everywhere with the specials and vegetables of the day, so you don't have to worry about remembering anything. They sat us downstairs as it was a hot day and apparently cooler down there which it was, but mostly due to the A/C blowing directly on our table (which I was fine with, the candles on the other hand, weren't as they kept burning down incredibly fast, but the servers were incredibly good about changing them out). They start you out with a bit of bread (their brown bread is heavenly) and some crudites with a bit of dressing. Yum.Food-wise everything we had was great. I started with the Stilton mousse and the other half got the pate. The mousse was spot on with a big blue cheese punch in the face served with perfectly toasted bread and a bit of salad. Yum. The bite of pate I had was also really well done. I ordered the steak and kidney pie for the main (but I almost went with the liver) and the other half got the venison special. I also ordered some chips (when in Britain, right?), red cabbage and cauliflower cheese as sides for the table to share. The pie was fan-freaking-tastic. It had a rich sauce and the taste of kidneys just came through the sauce amazingly. The crust was wonderfully cooked and delicious. (Unfortunately it was just a top crust pie, I could only imagine it as a full on pie!) The sides were all really well done, with the cauliflower cheese being a favorite. Lots of baked cheese on top and crunchy, tasty cauliflower. There's also a good wine list, and we had three different bottles, all of which were really nice bottles. You can also opt for the house wine where they measure how much you drink by the end of the night.For dessert, the other half and I split the bread pudding and the apple crumble. One of our friends ordered the Cambridge burnt cream. The bread pudding was thick and soft and spongy as a good bread pudding should be. It was a tad cold in the middle, but it didn't deter me from eating it. (A bit of warning for raisin haters, the bread pudding does indeed have raisins.) The crumble was well done, but not amazing. I did have a bite of the burnt cream and it was by far the winner. The cream is so flavorful and the burnt sugary topping was perfect.Oh Maggie, you brought me so much joy. I will recommend you to anyone who wants to go get British food, as you are one of the best.

u0kSUrZV5FR-I6RCpRFISw.text: Rustic decor, a candelight dinner, great service and a warm, cozy, home-like feeling...could this place get any better?  Doubtful.  The hubby and I went to Maggie Jones last night for dinner and I'm already looking forward to out next visit.  My rack of lamb with asparagus was heavenly and my hubby's steak fillet with mashed was delicious as well.  Maggies Jones is the perfect restaurant for a romantic dinner, a night out with friends or for visiting family members.

ULeZAmQfYKonDcK41UO4BA.text: A bit of a gem, down in an alley way. Set In a small, yet charming 3 level house. You get to eat surrounded by antiques. The place is mostly candle lit. Very romantic but boisterous in equal amounts which is a great mix. The food served here is what I imagine rich Victorians to feed on. I travel a lot and I've never seen PARTRIDGE on the menu. Expected alot of venison, boar along with traditional home made meat pies. They have a few veggie options too.Service is slow like molasses but I can only imagine how small the kitchen is in this old building, so I am willing to let it slide. Make sure to make an evening of it. Not a quick bite on the way to something else.

wLyZdCLK4V69yovGBS8UNQ.text: Stopped by at the last minute. Excellent food at a reasonable price, a charming space, and very good service.

1Vbq0AjES76shPP72DCSRQ.text: So glad I consulted a map first because otherwise finding this restaurant would have been awkward... Came here on a Sunday evening with my mom. Fell in love with the decor. This place is gorgeous and has a nice intimate vibe; especially the upstairs. I had the roast lamb and my mom had the fish pie. Everything tasted delicious. Service was friendly though a bit slow. Great meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom

_pLOxYvZIC-gnPToRu2iTA.text: From the US and this was Our favorite meal when visiting london.  The atmosphere is warm, inviting and casual.  Service excellent.  Food fabulous. I recommend the creme brule for dessert.  I found it, as I was in the area and looked on  yelp for a good place for dinner.  Thanks Yelpers you never let me down. HIghly recommend.

IaCLEs8tz4ZlGjc-qXSfTA.text: Was lucky enough to receive a gift of a voucher to this lovely place. The decor is quirky and crowded, giving you the feeling you're in the home of a generous, eccentric host with a very good cook. The perfect place for a romantic date or a special occasion. The rabbit was excellent.The wine comes in magnums, they bill you for the amount you've drunk!

axkd2946qaH-aRTu1RvYVQ.text: I can happily say with confidence that I have found my new favorite restaurant in London. On many previous trips/layovers in London I had peered through the dark outside widows and saw what appeared to be a very cozy atmosphere where diners were dining by beautiful warm candlelight. So, one of my good friends and renowned "foodie" and I decided to try Maggie Jones's. From the moment we entered the restaurant where we were promptly and warmly greeted by Patrice and Christine, I knew we were in for a treat! If you are like me, and love authentically rustic décor with dark stained hardwoods and candles glowing on every table, you too will fall in love with this amazing gem of a restaurant. The lovely jazz music from the 30s to the 50s adds to this unbelievable establishment's ambiance just as the hanging baskets with dried flowers do. Now, let's talk FOOD! The menu is simple, elegant and wholesome, yet, unique with interesting specials displayed on a movable chalk board that the servers bring to each booth or table. I have had the pleasure of being served by Oliver twice now and he is both personable and professional. The timing of the food delivery and presentation was spot on! I thoroughly enjoyed one of the freshly prepared salads as a starter and then, "as the Brits say", tucked in to a perfectly seasoned and deliciously cooked rump steak of lamb. The side dish of their baked cauliflower & cheese served in a mini iron skillet was delectable! If you choose to dine on the lower level, you can watch the amazing Portuguese chefs, Grace and Martin create their magic on a plate that I'm told they've been doing here for nearly 40 years. After an amazing dinner, we were given a full tour of the 3 level rustic wonderland known as Maggie Jones's along with some fun history about the former "home" now restaurant. The prices are neither inexpensive nor overpriced especially in London near Kensington! But I find the value more than fair for what I will call my favorite dining experience in 8 years of laying over in London on a weekly basis. Yes, I'm an international flight attendant who has had the good fortune of experiencing some amazing meals, especially in Paris and many other cities in Europe and South America. I have to say, Maggie Jones's is now at the top of my list!

0SfGtj5fgq2-IvTBVvreDw.text: Oh my god the cheesy cauliflower is amazing! Honestly, everything we had was excellent. The servers were very fun and friendly. The atmosphere was cute, cozy, and inviting. Great experience all around.

aCTzJJsNBjIw2abNBcPsjQ.text: I am 12 years old and this is some amazing food there is some great food I highly recommend smoke chicken and avocado salad and please go here it is GREAT!!!!!!!!!!

3Sy77l0No5PzQNwTPNIlEQ.text: Love it! I keep coming back for the vegetarian pot pie. Best mashed potatoes ever. Cute eclectic country decor is comfy and relaxing.

ZtpQ_iMY4Ww8SeztofD1mA.text: I simply cannot understand the good reviews for this place.  I might have given it 2 stars on the basis of food and price - I had a chunk of tough and overcooked lamb (ordered rare) for £18 with no accompaniments.  My partner had a rack of lamb that was mostly fat and also overcooked for £22.  Essentially the food was close to disgusting at very high prices, although the vegetables were ok at about £3-4 extra.What was shocking about this place was their attitude to gluten free.  The first waitress  (one of the senior ones) said I could eat almost anything if they left the sauce off - give her a couple of options and we could find something.  I took her at her word, although my wife subsequently told me that it was obvious she did not know what she was talking about.She never reappeared.  Instead I got a more junior waiter, who announced I could not have roast pork, venison, partridge or most of the limited items on the menu.  He suggested either pheasant or fish pie as being the only things I could eat.  He clearly had no clue, as fish pie is obviously not ok.To cut a long story short, the food here is overpriced, badly prepared and the staff are untrained and deceitful.  Avoid like the plague - by far the worst restaurant I have been to in London.

RW5UUk00pSRcSv4TJpRHEA.text: Best pot pie that I've ever had. I had the chicken and my friend had the fish pot pie. Good service in the quaint restaurant. No beer or liqour, but they do have wine. Apparently it's owned by Italians, who definitely know how to cook English food! Will come back next time we visit London.

tLKcKzU34U8IyeadoW86Zg.text: I loved this place. We never settle for touristy eateries near landmarks. We like to look on yelp for something different with an excellent rating. My husband found this one. We almost gave up on it as we could not find it at first but I am so glad that we did. We were the first ones there for the evening. The staff were warm and welcoming and the waiter..the skinny french guy(I think French) was so funny and sweet. They let us sit upstairs. The food was delicious. I am still sad to this day that I did not order the roast chicken like our son. I am still craving it 2 months later. My fish pie was delicious. I loved the decor. I showed the pictures to my sister and her kids and the funniest comment I got was that it looked like Shrek and Fiona should be dining there....please do not take that as an insult. I thought it was cute. The most amusing thing for us was that they seated 2 older couples at the table next to us. Low and behold we heard them talking about Bart and other San Francisco transport. What are the odds the only two table occupied upstairs would have people from San Francisco. The food fresh and made from scratch and the decor adorable. I found that the food in Britain smells like I remember food smelling when I was a kid. It has no preservatives and it just smelt delicious. The only thing is that I can never remember the name. We have a supermarket close by called Mollie Stones and I always end up calling this place Mollie Jones. I could not yelp it yesterday because I had to wait until the guys got home so that I could ask them the name of the restaurant...pretty worrying at 45..LOL

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Roast Chicken..Delicious
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Fish Pie
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Wild Boar Sausage and Mash

WP0ZLOwWt6gpVcCDLgOfuQ.text: Delicious food, charming candlelit atmosphere, terrific waitstaff, and Patrice!  He was delightful and accommodating on a Saturday evening.  We will be back.

lV8lFxhsCRhuAfSYC0i2GQ.text: My wife, daughter, and I came here because of the good rating here on yelp. Not sure how it got so many stars because it was unimpressive. It had a nice atmosphere, with candles on top of wine glasses and the feel of an old english home kitchen.The service was really slow and we had to flag our waiter down multiple times. I had the steak and kidney pie, which was just okay. My wife had the salmon with hollandaise, which had bones in the salmon still. I tried the bread and butter pudding which was so disappointing. The bread part was actually good but the sauce was so plain. It tasted like a can of warmed up tapioca pudding.

6jx3WzlseRJ6ALBtB53Nfw.text: I am an American living in London for 10 months so far.  This is the best British food I've had since I've moved here.  The services was slow and not terribly helpful, however,  If the food wasn't so good, the service I received would really put me off.  I was with a friend and a business guest.  When I tried to order our starters to buy us some time to think about main courses, I was told by our server that starters must be ordered at the same time as the entrees.  We didn't buy that and think that the waiter just didn't want to have to take our orders separately for starters and main courses.The appetisers were small and rustic and at first underwelmed, but one taste of the hollandaise and we were in!  For dinner, the roast rump of lamb with mint was the star, but my roast beef rump with onions and horseradish was also very good.  The sea bream was good but full of bones, and I have no patience for that :)Desserts were amazing.  The chocolate pot, bread and butter pudding and sherry trifle were all stars.I'd go here again and hope for a different server.

AVs13VuQ3IjgSvaRdFzKnQ.text: FANTASTIC! Best romantic setting in Kensington. Delicious food! Great people and service. A must go for Sunday Roast and night time is fantastic all lit by candles

PXAIm6M37mJrRK3wf3osuA.text: Now I live in the US I was seriously craving some proper British food. So imagine my excitement when my friend brings me here! Not only is the restaurant beautiful but the food is spectacular. I had the pate and the wild boar sausages with peas and spinach - heavenly!!!  Huge portion sizes. I also had a bite of my friends pork which was divine. I can't recommend this place enough and will be back here every time I visit London!

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom

ubpekkLemhuY397QWuIxiA.text: Had a bit of everything: pepper sirloin, grilled salmon, lamb & chicken with tarragon sauce. The lamb with mint sauce was cooked to perfection and was the absolute favorite. Wrapped up dinner with Apple crumble with cream and a coffee. Coffee came with a gallon of milk on the side (I asked for cream or milk) and the huge mug made us laugh hysterically. Service was sweet but took a bit of time to get our food. We sat in a corner booth and for a while it felt way to dark, like medieval times, trying to read the wine menu by candle light (literally). For a moment we thought about asking for a second or third candle or even travel back to modern times and use a light. I guess they really did a good job with the ambience and decorations. The place was great. Yes, all good things are expensive so be prepared for that.

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Milk with coffee

W3LvDeGPEGgL_Sre68LrRQ.text: Went here with my fiancé for lunch as our first stop in London. We wanted to eat at a traditional British pub and this place was great. The atmosphere was the best part about this place, and it felt very authentic. No tourists, just straight up British cuisine (pies, roasts, vegetables etc.) would definitely come back just for the ambiance. We got the fish pie and the rump of steak for entrees. Both were tasty. Our favorite meal was the dessert, Bread and Butter pudding with custard, it was absurdly good. Service was fast and everyone was very nice.

oow28HjRjtec6XCKYB-z6Q.text: As British at it gets (except for the staff who is not). Old, intimate environment, perfect for a date. Hot tip: arrive hungry! Big portions of proper British food, and they have great specials on top of a good a la carte menu. We had rump of lamb and guinea fowl, accompanied by mashed potatoes and cheesy cauliflower, and two kinds of gravy. Excellent wine as well!

Gt5ETdRD1nrkSF3BKZHk4A.text: You could walk past Maggie Jones and never see it. Upon walking in, all your senses start sparking. Interesting, upscale, cozy, vaguely romantic and instantly you're quite interested in sitting down and ordering because you know it's going to be a most pleasant experience. They've captured something special here and they're proud to share it with you. The food is wonderful and inspired. I had stuffed pork with apple (crunchy fat back, tender and salty sweet) and crisp fresh French green beans. One table mate had the guinea fowl (difficult to ensure moist succulence) and the other had Chicken with Tarragon sauce. We had dessert (shouldn't have but well worth the extra minutes in the gym). Apple crumbles with cream and lemon Sorbet. I fly to London 3-4 times a month and while there are many wonderful restaurants none are worth going back to regularly. Maggie Jones just became my Go-To Must-Go place. I regret telling about it but from the number of people there on a Sunday night--I'm not the only fan. I could eat here every time I visit and most certainly will.

C0YV0kQB8g8oukfimuJrNg.text: When it's cold outside and you're longing for something a bit traditional, this is the place to go. The food is rich and warm and filling. There are a lot of options for pies, slow-cooked cuts of meat, etc.  It's in a bit of a funny place, on a tiny side street near Kensington High Street. We sat upstairs surrounded by all sort of knick-knacks and baskets hanging from the ceiling. Thinking about it makes me want to go back!Gluten-free notes: Much of the food was naturally gluten free, it was not difficult to find something to eat. Be sure to ask about flour in gravy, etc.

PmqWEuouYZBi9k2CMBGjyg.text: Wonderful eclectic English restaurant. Super service and believe it or not we would've rather sat in cellar - not a 5 star as while good nothing exceptional about food we had - sea been and chicken - however the "burned cream" aka crime brûlée was about the best we had. Our waiter was Daniel and he was friendly and interested.

0l86xoctdW0-qHFuLPEM9A.text: Had the rosemary garlic rack of lamb with Cheesy cauliflower as a side.  It was SUBLIME.  Totally great, but a bit pricey. That and two bottles of beer came in at almost 50 quid.  But really good. Really cute and a great place for a date night.  Unfortunately, I was solo on a corp business account (well maybe the part that my company was paying was good!?)

kkiH6CCGE-wiz5vP1g68Zw.text: What an amazing experience!  Such a quaint place.  The chicken and artichoke pie was exceptionally scrumptious.  The venison medallions was a special of the night and was wonderful.  Topped off the meal with the burnt cream aka English creme brulee and I couldn't have asked for a better Birthday meal during our visit to London.  This is a must go to restaurant either whilst visiting or if you live there. Also the waitress Suzy was a delight and such a doll.

LIXfEgWQCOoWtV-44GddjQ.text: Enjoyed every moment of my Valentine's Day lunch with my wife at Maggie Jones. The atmosphere was comfortable, inviting and romantic. We enjoyed the asparagus with hollandaise, French onion soup, fish pie, bacon and Stilton salad and an apple crumble. Will return again for a special occasion.

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom

LZk98UZCjZcbYXb2M6bDmw.text: Outstanding food!  The staff was friendly and professional.  Portions were very large and tasty!

4UvkP_qg-Djl5nHnLWLjCw.text: Incredible. Can't ask for a more authentic experience. Roast chicken, gravy and brad sauce were great. Amazing ambiance and the bread pudding is really good. Amazing ambiance - from the creaky floorboards and rustic atmosphere to the lighting steaming through the windows. To top it all off, the service was extremely friendly and accessible. Wish I had this as my neighborhood go-to.

bcV-SYBvbO-ssJEsbys33w.text: Eclectic and fun, dimly list, candles, friendly staff - great atmosphere...Good place for a small get together, there is a larger table on the main level that can accommodate a reasonably sized gathering.  Food is exactly what you'd expect, simple but tasty and supplemented by a reasonable set of bar options.Great spot for visitors...

CsbKdn1WAif-xdY49mPwZQ.text: One of the best restaurants I've tried in London. Loved the rustic, cozy decor. My friend and I both enjoyed our lamb and wine very much. When our waiter realized that he had initially failed to bring us our drinks, he offered us a dessert complimentary on the house. No complaint on that especially since our creame brulee was delicious. Look forward to coming back here someday.

YwrFFef9AHu6qZL1ofEdvg.text: I'd been in London all of 12 hours (most of it sleeping off jet lag)  when it was time for dinner + some wine.  I yelped for an hour and found a few places that looked good within walking distance of my hotel, but by the time I got outsidel I decided to wander and I'm so glad that I did.  Just 10 min from my hotel, I stumbled upon a cute little, well lit front of Maggie Jones's.  They had just opened - it was quarter past six. The staff was friendly, the specials were delightful: I got the crab and avocado appetizer -- served on a bed of arugula and other greens.  It was a very healthy portion.  Followed by the root vegetable pot pie -- again a generous portion.  The crust was made fresh, it was perfect.  Pot of chocolate for dessert and this kid is ready for bed again.

60JhFJOHlc2ni65pMfrTGw.text: if you are wondering where to take out of town guests ... for a memorable evening - this is the place.  your old auntie's attic meets a contemporary take on british and european classic dishes.  the ambiance is fun, eclectic, random, chaotic but somehow all very relaxing.  wait-staff were foodies and knew their stuff.  sufficiently patient and thick skinned to handle a largish and animated crowd. (sorry - but we were good tippers so everyone went home happy i hope).  love their potted pies and the large carafs of red wine!  love this place

jt7xf9x_EpsS_QZpspzx7Q.text: Visited this gem of a restaurant on New Years Eve on my first night in London (as recommended by a friendly local on the street... thank you!). Upon entering the dimly lit restaurant, we were greeted by the cheery staff who were all dressed in fun costumes. The place was decorated with streamers and the tables sprinkled with confetti and party poppers. Service throughout the night was exceptional. Every waiter ensured that we enjoyed our experience. As for the food, it was a New Years Eve set menu for £40/person. For starters, I had the "Maggie's Tart," which comprised of soft warm eggs and spinach. The tart was cooked to perfection! For the main, I had the "Chicken & Artichoke Pie." Again, the chefs knocked it out of the park. The top crust had just the right amount of crisp. The pie was packed with chicken too. The main came with sautéed spinach and purple cabbage, both of which complimented the pie well. To end the night, I had the bread pudding. Despite how full I was, this pudding had to the best I have ever tasted. The pudding itself was not overly sweet. The bread had a crispy outer edge, soft, spongy center, and raisins  for added punch of flavor.Staff, food, and atmosphere all taken into account... a definite 5 out of 5. I would love to explore the rest of their menu whenever I return to London in the future!

he39QcIqgbapNqzza63MeQ.text: Undeniably quaint and romantic setting! Once through the front door, I am transported back to a simpler time. The interior looks like an medieval tavern, rustic and charming. The wooden narrow staircase led us to the second floor. Large baskets with dry flowers/wheat decorate the ceiling beams. Tall candles in champagne bottles are everywhere. Tall wooden booths and tables are lay out though this narrow floor plan. It's dark and intimate, and I love it! The service is polite and prompt. The Louie dressing with my Shrimp Cocktail with arugula is delicious. The Rump of Lamb with garlic & Rosemary taste juicy, seasoned, pan seared and cooked to the right temperature. My wife's Pork shoulder is succulent as well! The meats are served by it self, so ordering a side of potatoes chips and sautéed spinach are the perfect accompaniments! This is a must stop in London!

lrHNrRVP1SjgDec6THJwwg.text: I'm not sure how this place has so many stars. Maybe they changed wait staff and chef. Where to begin...The atmosphere was cute they put candlesticks in champagne bottles. However, that was about the only thing we liked about this place. To start we ordered steak, quiche, and soup. We told them to bring things out as they were ready. 45 minutes went by and we hadn't seen any food. At an hour we said something and a nice man who was not our waitress looked very confused and went and checked on our food. Apparently the waitress (very rude and unprofessional) told them to bring our food out all together. Why I don't know because we said several times we were hungry and to bring things out as ready.  After an hour and twenty minutes our food came out and the waitress said "sorry there were a lot of big parties downstairs." Just to be clear there were none when we arrived and only one table of six when we left. Also not a very professional way to handle the situation. The food itself was quite bland. Really nothing good to say about it. After that long we were expecting great food, and it wasn't good. As we were paying, the table next to us (that had the same waitress) complained because apparently she got one person's order completely wrong. She once again was missing, not to deal with the problems she caused. The same poor waiter had to fix her mess. As we left we saw her do nothing in the corner while the other waiter got yelled at because of her mistakes! I couldn't believe it. She didn't care at all and didn't apologize to their table. What really set me off (I don't think I've ever given a one star review and rarely a two star..) is that I got severe food poisoning from this place. Did I mention it started on my 11 hour flight back to the states. Do not go here!!!!

9U57EM1I6ORKQD4o6VyDnQ.text: We went here for dinner on the recommendation of our tour guide. What a find! Food was top notch, surpassed only by the service. The atmosphere is laid back and a little kooky. If I ever find myself in London again, I will definitely stop here.

worksm0ZU8B57AXwHxgCPQ.text: Honestly, this may be one of my most pleasing restaurant experiences lately. The interior different and unusual, something that makes you impression when you first come in, which makes me like this place even more. The atmosphere is unique, cosy, and welcoming.The food here tastes authentic and fantastic, as well as the service. I like their selection of traditional English dishes. The food seems to be prepared with freshly picked products and with care, almost feeling like the meals are home-made. Prices are a bit high, but I find them reasonable for the quality of the food.Maggie Jones's is a place  I will be definitely visiting more often.

19cnwfMBQfUwSvfguE8Z_Q.text: Such an authentic British restaurant. The food was delicious, but the decor and candlelight put this place over the top. I loved it and will definitely return. Get the bread pudding!

_jg6jbFwVO5pbJOyoLfhRQ.text: A real gem of a place hidden out of the way in a neighbourhood devoid of good lunch options outside of the usual sushi chains, etc. The atmosphere (dark, candles, etc.) is a perfect antidote to the bustle of London.Had the celery soup to start followed by the spinach tart, both of which I would happily have again and again.  Service was fantastic too; wasn't rushed and the main waiter was friendly in exactly the right way. Will be back.

DuNybC39fiFdND97fNH70g.text: WOW! Maggie Jone's extremely delicious! My friend took me there after we just left from a exhibition and it was the perfect place for the end of our day.The decoration is cool and it makes you feel like you are in some family cozy house, from what I understand they have a new menu everyday. The whole crew is very kind and funny and they seem to know every plate as they are the one that would cook it.I had the veggie pie which was the best one I ever had and I'm not lying, my friend got the duck with some potatoes and veggies with was melting in the mouth. The house wine is also really good both red and white and I can't forget about the bread! what a bread! I look forward to go back there

LZZX-D5r18LuQx-JmHCBAw.text: A nice little restaurant just off the beaten path. Food was fresh and delicious. If visiting London and looking for a unique local restaurant with a great staff, fantastic food and great ambiance this is the place.

LoZPXZfcXpF5NXcpPCc3Ig.text: All I can say is WOW!! My friend and I were in London and looking for a great place to eat on a Saturday night. We were extremely lucky to find Maggie Jones! When we walked in we quickly realized this was a place where reservations should have been made. But the staff was amazingly accommodating and we were able to get a beautiful booth. The restaurant is dark and has an eclectic feel of the English countryside. The food was superb! I had the lamb and the moment I tasted it I felt as if it may have the best thing I've ever eaten! I didn't want it to end! Let's just say our meal didn't feel like a meal but rather an event of wonderful flavors, coupled with incredible service! I am so sad that I live in LA and will not have a chance to eat here again until next spring. You can bet the moment the plane touches the ground, you know where I'll be headed!!

7sAgI4EpipOKKx_awtJseA.text: Very romantic and rustic restaurant in the heart of Kennsington gardens.We were seated without reservations on a week night. We sat in the upstairs dining area on a metal garden table. It was very quaint. Lights are dim and the scene is rustic romantic.  I would advise this place for a romantic night out for dinner.

yw49zXlFVuZSyvjLrtyv3g.text: I loved this place-- I will 100% be coming back here next time I find myself in London.First of all, it's adorable.  The decor is so rustic, I loved it.The staff was amazing, they were so friendly.The food-- so good. Simple food done right. I will say that my lamb was a little over cooked, but it was still amazing. They offered to bring me out mint jelly without me asking too. My very picky boyfriend and travel companions loved it all. They best part was when they caught be putting some salt on the pot de creme-- they looked at me like I was crazy! We had a lot of laughs as I assured them it was amazing, and I'm sure they tried it later lol.

P_Qwy7kpbY8Nq3aapWC7SQ.text: Sadly, I was quite disappointed again, for such a lovely and cosy place. This being my third time, only because my friend who organised the annual get together chose this place, and I was willing to give it another try.I have yet to understand the rave reviews regarding the food though, but it may be it is because we always go for the Sunday Set Menu and not a la carte, which is difficult to get on a Sunday it seems, more of that later.So the first time, had a great impression of the place because of the impressive decor.  We were seated upstairs, and I loved the cosiness, but the food was so, so, no refinement in cooking or presentation, standard fare really.The second time, our party was seated downstairs, and as I could not stay for long and would not have time for the full Sunday set lunch, asked to order just a main course from their a la carte menu.  What a palaver, it seems this is not available on Sundays. Finally, after much to-ing and fro-ing, and exasperation on the part of the harassed waiters, I was able to just order a fish dish that they will prepare for me, but the fish they offered was not available, so had the alternative, which tasted very bland.So third time lucky?  Well let see, our group was seated downstairs, and we had all pre-ordered except two people, who were then given the Sunday Set Menu on a blackboard.  I had the roast pork, which was very dry, and then realised that there should have been gravy to accompany it, and when I looked for the gravy boat, it was at the other end of the table, and was empty.  I managed to attract a waitress' attention as she passed me to serve another table, and I had not expected her to neglect the other table to serve me, but her attitude was a bit rude, when I tried to get her attention.  Finally, after waiting for her to come back, and she did not, I asked another waiter who happened to pass by with his hands full, and I mentioned if he could help me, and he looked at his full hands and I immediately, expressed, obviously, when he was ready. In no way was I expecting him to drop everything!I was surprised that they only supplied one gravy boat for seven Sunday roasts, on a large table. To make matters worst, whilst I tried to explain to the busy, stressed out waiter, the other waitress took the gravy boat and filled it up and left it at the other end of the table to me, so it was out of reach, and the people at the other end, thought "great more gravy", obviously not enough before, and proceeded to hand it around at their end, amidst protests from me!  I was slightly miffed that the waitress did not return the gravy boat to me since I specifically asked for it, it would have been much better customer service to do so.My companion had lamb, and he said that was very chewy. The roast beef and sea bream were probably the better bet, although one person was not happy that the beef was well done, when they requested otherwise.  Again the service was lacking.  The person who had the sea bream, after finishing his meal, spied a dish of baby potatoes at the far end of the table, untouched, and thought that was probably for his dish, and he would have liked some, if he saw it.  Again, why put it at the other end of the table to the person who should have it. At any other restaurant, the waiter would announce the arrival of the sides, or put it with or near the person who had ordered that meal. I know they are busy but the waiter/waitress looked stressed and harassed, and not at all welcoming, and if that is their mood, then that rubs off on the overall restaurant atmosphere, creating an unrelaxed place. I had expected a better level of service and better quality food in South West London. Luckily, the company we had was great, and I hope the organiser will choose somewhere else next time for our get together.

knUU-besUphKccQcTblHWg.text: Always a pleasure to eat here.  The ambiance is warm and quaint with absolutely wonderful service.  The food is delicious, wonderfully prepared and excellent choices for everyone.  I wish they were on OpenTable so I would remember to book them more frequently but they are worth calling to ensure I get a table.  Going to Maggie Jone's is always a good choice!!!

nMIEOr8qszE07jA5-5b_lg.text: The food was simple but tasty. The real star here is the restaurant itself - so quaint and charming with candles, rustic decor and lovely dishware. The bread and butter pudding with custard was to die for.

wi1PL1hgkZoNy8gtH1aRLg.text: If you love The Crown on Netflix, you'll love Maggie Jones.  It was a favorite of Princess Margaret and Lord Snowden, she used Maggie Jones as her alias when making a reservation.  I had the Stuffed Chicken Tarragon, the best comfort food in London.  The ambience is very cozy and you never know who you might be dining with.  There were a couple of royals when we first visited.

IlzZWwX11Sgny-i-Rb7Pag.text: All-day dining on a Saturday. Comfy-cozy decor perfect in a cold winter day. The soup of the day...mushroom...is delicious comfort food for the soul. Friendly service. Nice and quiet for couples, perfect girl-friends lunch, or great for families with kids. Yummy traditional British cuisine with a dash of French influence. The two-course set lunch was the perfect amount of food. The roasted chicken in the chicken avocado salad was super-yummy. Twelve.five percentage service charge included. Now, I need to try the sister restaurant La Poule a Pot. maggie-Jones.co.uk info@maggie-jones.co.uk

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom

OPK_Bp4QtOmMovLO2Qx0_A.text: A local friend recommended Maggie Jones's to us so we stopped by after Kensington Gardens.  The decor is very nice and quaint, while the service and food is delicious.  We started with Venison Terrine & Duck Liver Pate, both were really great and served with a salad that had a yummy vinaigrette on it.  Between the 5 of us we also had the Onion Pie, French Onion Soup, Fish Pie, Wild Boar Sausage&Mash, and Rump of Lamb.  Everything was so good (can't attest to the fish pie as I have a mushroom allergy but my friends loved it).  The French Onion Soup was probably the best I've ever tasted. I would definitely recommend stopping in for a bite if you are in the neighborhood!

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Duck Liver Pate
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Wild Boar Sausage
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Venison Terrine

utzu4FO3x4L78j_GQDwSFw.text: My family stopped in here on our last night in London. It's a small quaint place right near Kensington Gardens. The place is small but they manage to fit a lot of ambiance into it. We didn't have a reservation but they were able to find us a spot. The menu is seasonal and had a number of items that looked like they would be worth a go. We had the fish pie and the rump of lamb. Both were very well cooked. I quire enjoyed my rump of lamb. We also got the crab and avocado and duck pate starters. Definitely worth a stop.

9Y69FawWHMuJu6_pqAaxlA.text: Looking for a quaint English country side restaurant?  You found your place at Maggie jones.  Looks like an old traditional pub with the benches with doors.  The food is excellent .  Had the French onion soup , steak and kidney pie and steak filet all cooked and seasoned to perfections. Staff is friendly and knowledgeable.

9B5s6bC-3q-IRJPhNWsTjg.text: Great experience, the food was delicious, you can tell it was made from the bottom with fresh ingredients. The service was also good.

7dDBEK0aGsw3MykNkvUytg.text: We had a delicious dinner here, but it was a little too expensive. We had other equally delicious meals in London but spent less. The food was fresh - I had the chicken artichoke pie, and my husband had the sirloin steak. Really well cooked food, and attentive service.

TcuX7omv7m1__ZDrNz66NQ.text: Stumbled onto this place for an awesome lunch. The service was great, even though they were quite busy at the time. Great decor throughout their restaurant, which sets a nice mood and prepares you for some amazing food. I was a big fan of their salmon, Brussels sprouts, and roast.

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom

l-iuHOlZQ2KI9cPeViBMvg.text: Very good restaurant, good foods nice decorated...look like hobbit restaurant or dwarf restaurant...make you feel like a snow white...i just love the wooden furniture with traditional crockery. Lavender displayed on the table.Good selections of menu on the board. Everything is good but only find that hard to share your seat with some big bear...u just need to find a way to squeeze in. Oh.yeah..im lazy to write...in summary..all dishes we ordered are very delicious...dishes photos attached..take a look

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom

XEFTlaGRH9cQFtuBvO86hg.text: I saw this place on Instagram and was like "wow so pretty must eat there for Instagram purposes"  - which I did, but I also want to advise you that the service was great.  The decor is super cozy and the lighting is super cozy, at nighttime I imagine it's even cozier but I wasn't there after dark so this will remain a mystery to me until the end of time.Only small complaint was that if you order the veggie pot pie, they could use some non-vegetarian sides to go along with it.  I'm not one though, so I ate so much ham on my peas.  If I ever return to London I will go here again and take more pictures for my Instagram which has a whopping 360 followers (try not to be too jealous).

e2wIhRuXU3DoDjr7QapUKQ.text: Very cozy and romantic spot. At the same time I saw a lot of families with kids eating here. It's unfussy but seriously good food at reasonable prices.French onion soup (5/5) - one of the best renditions I've ever had. The right balance of everything and not too watery.Lamb rump (4/5) - beautiful cut and perfectly cooked. Good hits of rosemary and olive oil on this solid execution They provide some nice crudités too. Service was friendly and attentive.Basically nice neighborhood joint!

uuhj-jD14n1l5ZIuA6qlkg.text: Love this place! Rustic and sexy! Beautifully prepared food! Very friendly and gracious staff. I can't wait to go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom

EqYSa_P95aRuLaatJwmQYg.text: This was my favorite place we ate in London. The restaurant itself is so well decorated and beautiful and cozy. I had the chicken and artichoke pie and it was divine. Service was friendly and quick, which is far from a promise in London. Really enjoyed Maggie's!

YuB_bQxKH1JomXROrZ2z-A.text: Classic British fare in an intimate setting. We started with a Stilton mousse that was flavorful but not overpowering. Main for me was their chicken artichoke pie.  I finished with their apple crumble that was tasty and not too sweet. I should add that when they are in season, the globe artichokes are a complete success. Service is impeccable.

pfp0cIZz9IvHch9g52Mx-Q.text: Maggie Jones's was a little hard for us to find, but the atmosphere was incredibly romantic and intimate. The food wasn't quite what I had expected or hoped, but the drinks, service, and ambience deserve much praise.

mL89c3GuQsQ1zNLJXX655g.text: I'm a little conflicted over this review because Maggie Jones's has a lot of charm. But here goes...The good:The decor and ambience is great -- complete with candlelight, eclectic furniture, mismatched plates and cutlery. Very welcoming with loads of character.The staff is friendly and attentive and totally professional.My starter, onion soup, was excellent. Seriously good. But the problem is that it raised my expectations very high. The main course:The roast chicken was presented beautifully with perfectly rendered skin and a fantastic deep color. Unfortunately it was on the dry side and the seasoning was uneven. My friend ordered the steak and kidney pie. Again, the presentation was beautiful -- very traditional with a deep colored crust. Unfortunately the steak had burnt during searing and when it was deglazed that burnt taste spread throughout the entire filling. The sides: chip were over-fried and the gravy was over-seasoned. The cauliflower cheese however was very nice. For dessert we ordered the apple crumble which was very traditional and lovely. Unfortunately the custard had a flowery under taste that I couldn't quite place and took away from the dish. Even so, I think this place is wonderful. Everything tasted homemade and even though it was a little hit or miss, the heart of this place is unmistakable.

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom

Y27bT0XvyRhbomqH_LfuSQ.text: Stumbled across this place while leaving Kensington Palace. What a gem of a find. The service is excellent and the food is impeccable. Their spinach quiche and said is mouth-watering delicious. If you find yourself near here- check this place out!

photos.caption: Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Upstairs vibes! Cute atmosphere with unique decor.
Photo of Maggie Jones's - London, United Kingdom. Spinach quiche, filling enough just as the main meal.

iJW6CmUfG2ZyeYtuS_DtCQ.text: Want a Romantic lunch or dinner? EAT HERE!! Maggie Jones is such a charming, beautiful restaurant!! An absolute gem. DO NOT let the construction out front on the street, steer you away. (If downstairs, maybe ask for a table away from the front window).  We had found it through the Rick Steves guide and are glad we followed his advice.My husband and I had a delicious lunch which, with the quality of food, seemed a great value and bargain. Duck Liver Pate was delicious, as was our main, the stuffed roast pork. LARGE PORTIONS great for sharing.An absolute charming, romantic gem. Maggie Jones deserves 6 stars!

MVIuQ2T33Zyo6SykEnUJwg.text: Great ambience and a wonderful menu!  Romantic setting and traditional English fare!  Yes, we will be back!

gbQo0ksUJtrkB0pdr1YlXg.text: Interesting decour - food varied from very good to poor. When large groups came in, restaurant became cramped and stuffy with not enough staff to handle both our group of 4 (we felt a bit neglected) when they were dealing with the large group.  Passed on desert.

PyeAb7WSaPyfjtmBxIE1Rg.text: Unique eclectic setting which is much appreciated compared to the mostly generic restaurants lining nearby Kensington High Street. I felt like I was a grandmother's house with baskets of dried flowers lining the ceiling, wax-dripped wine bottles posing as candlestick on each table, and jazzy old-school music. The food was solid (my husband and I both got salads which were good, but not the best. fresh nonetheless) and the kind service and cool neighborhood buzz about it means it will definitely get a repeat visit from us.

plpNMVU_R1SPNdzABSTpKw.text: One of my favourite long lunch restaurants. Great British food, (roasts, pies, leek in cheese sauce, treacle pud, (yum), lots of specials. Most of the seating is in little booths, and you can get crammed in sometimes, but it's worth it. Lots of dried flowers and old bits of furniture and equipment dotted around. Wine is served in large carafes and you only pay for what you drink, which can be dangerous as it is always on the table. Love this restaurant, going to go and book it now, it's the perfect time of year.

Lxw3euP6sPrbNIsmTYTZtQ.text: I must have walked past this restaurant hundreds of times, but this afternoon was the first time I had dined at this lovely restaurant. Located just off Kensington Church Street (High Street Kensington end), one of our colleagues recommended this to me and my other female colleague, Emma. As Emma is leaving for a new job in a couple of weeks, we thought we'd enjoy going out for lunch before she goes. It's really quaint inside, we were warmly greeted and although the place was reasonably busy, we managed to get a table. We looked at the lunch special menu, and we ordered steak and kidney pie (which came with free sides of peas & carrots). The plates that the food were served on were really cute (country style), and most importantly the pie and vegetables (which counted towards my 5 a day ;-)) was delicious. Obviously no meal is complete without a dessert and the waiters brought a blackboard to show us what was on offer, Emma had bread & butter pudding and I had apple crumble and cream  let's just say, it didn't take long before we finished! The lunch menu was reasonable in cost, our meals together with a drink (and service charge) came to about £20 each. All in all, both Emma and I thought the food and service was soo good, we're making this one of our favourites. Good hearty English food in the heart of Kensington. Just BEAUTE :-)

hk4hGuoQhgWN3FnUDFMJrA.text: This place is a rare treat. I only get there once every few years (it can be a bit pricey), but when I do it's fab. What an amazing English restaurant (yes, it's English grub). But they specialise in Game. So if you want the best Duck, Venison, Pheasant or Wild Boar, this is the place. But even roat chicken is brilliant. Not to mention all the veg, salads, yorkies, etc. It's very quirky, with farm related stuff everywhere, old bicycles, wagon wheels, spades (you name it) stuffed into every nook and cranny (of which there are loads). The tables are scrubbed pine and the chairs are quirky too (even a few church pews) - but still comfy). It's very dimly lit, but it adds to the atmosphere. Waiter are very friendly and just the right side of cheeky. the salad dressing is the best I have ever tasted. I have begged them to give me the recipe for years but they wont. LOL! It's al good and you can't get a bad meal here. Save it for spesh and save up a bit first and have a great time. But be careful as the servings are big (even at lunch time). Best dessert: Burnt Treacle Creme Brulee. Yummy. Oh, BTW, they serve a great house wine and they charge you by the inch. I kid you not, they bring a ruler and measure how much you have drunk at the end. Fun! A really really different, intimate and superb restaurant.

2qBjPD8S8cjfB3p6jvbBdg.text: what I liked about this restaurant is the atmosphere, it's a really nice place for a date or a couple, nice service and good food. If you go on a weekend it's recomended a reservation, I will go there again!

4VMlRbFGp5LQ50TvsKMIKA.text: Maggie Jones' is a wonderful place. Staffed by some of the nicest waiters in the universe, this restaurant is a like a ramshackle farmhouse over three floors. Rough hewn wood and rickety furniture is accompanied by all manner of rural oddities hanging from the walls and ceiling. It's an exceptional date venue with the tables for two being discrete little booths and the majority of the lighting being candles. The food is excellent and entirely English. The sauteed oyster mushrooms, rocket and parmesan salad is my favourite starter though the selection of soup, globe artichoke, corn on the cob provide good competition. For mains, it is mostly roasts and grilled fish but all delicious in my experience. It's definitely worth checking out the specials board as there is always something worth considering. The wine list is mostly french though there is an Argentinian Malbec on the menu that I can't go past. All up it's one of my favourite local restaurants for an intimate date or a larger dinner.

MIaQ_M0oXCm0JzLSBZMvTw.text: Great for long lunches and hearty fare. Very English decor and sensibility to take visitors from overseas.
